characters: EXT HEAD FIRST SPORTS BAR / PAUL'S RENTAL CAR /

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stephen Meyers, Press Secretary to Governor Morris is standing at a podium on a stage...there is a single spotl on him. The rest of the stage is dark. Stephen is talking into a mic with no emotion...just matt of factly.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: I am neither Christian...nor atheist. I am not Jewish or Muslim. What I believe...my religion is called the constitution... A pause. Stephen snaps his fingers in the mic. We hear the distinc sound of feedback getting louder until it stops. We hear the director speak over the loud speaker.

dialogues.speaker: DIRECTOR
dialogues.text: Hang on...let me open these up.... We wait as Stephen looks around. He looks at stage hands are busy working. No one pays any attention to him as he stands there. This isn't awkward for Stephen, THIS IS ROUTINE.

dialogues.speaker: DIRECTOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Okay... Lights come up on another podium revealing a debate stage Stephen continues.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: I will defend till my dying breath your right to worship whatever god you believe in... The lights on Stephen's podium go out, he's in the dark. keeps going.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If I'm not religious enough for you, don't vote for me. To the Director. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You got it? His podium light comes back on. No answer from the Director, Stephen continues.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If I'm not experienced enough don't vote for me. If I'm not...

dialogues.speaker: DIRECTOR
dialogues.text: Okay got it, thanks.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: Thanks. We'll need these monitors turned up a bit...it's a big space and he wants to be able to hear.

dialogues.speaker: STAGE MANAGER
dialogues.text: You got it.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: Also we'll need these podiums put on a riser as we agreed to in the pre-conditions. You're a few inches short and it makes it harder for the Governor to read his notes.

dialogues.speaker: STAGE MANAGER
dialogues.text: No I know, we just got those specs last night and they're building a piece to go under...

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: Great, thanks. See you guys ina few hours. We see we're in an auditorium of a college. Stephen meets up with BEN HARPEN his staffer.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: I didn't know the Governor had trouble reading his notes. Why doesn't he wear...

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: He doesn't but Pullman is 5'8" he'll look like a hobbit behind that podium. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They walk off...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ROB BRAUN, a local Cincinnati anchor, talks to camera as see STEPHEN and BEN exit the building. Under this we hear Rachel Maddow reporting.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL MADDOW, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: Well it all comes down to this...We are one week away from the Ohio primary... Camera now moves past ROB to another news truck where an MSNBC REPORTER stands in front of a camera waiting to go live. There is a monitor in front of him. The camera keeps moving into the monitor where RACHEL MAD does the lead in. As RACHEL's audio continues we see the following images.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We cruise along a snow-covered rural landscape - flat, gr desolate. In the distance we see a barn with huge red-whi and-blue letters painted on the side. They read "OHIO FOR MORRIS".

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL MADDOW, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Two democrats are left standing. Senator Pullman of Arkansas who is trailing Governor Morris from Pennsylvania. Moments later we roll past another farm with a large billboard staked into the ground beside the road: "PULLMA AMERICA'S FUTURE BEGINS ON MARCH 15th".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We cut to canvassers - bundled to the hilt against the co knocking on doors in a suburban neighborhood. Yard signs both candidates line the street. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL MADDOW, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Governor Morris has mounted a sizable lead with 2047 delegates, winning New Hampshire, California, New York and Michigan...But Senator Pullman with 1302 delegates is still in the hunt having won Florida, Tennessee, Virginia and Missouri...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Supporters at an intersection waving hand-made signs to c "HONK FOR MORRIS". A passing car lays on the horn and the supporters cheer.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL MADDOW, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: A win in Ohio could turn it all around for the Arkansas Senator... CLOSE UP of a Pullman bumper sticker on an SUV at a stoplight, right next to a "My Child is an Honor Student" decal.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL MADDOW, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: So one week from Tuesday the all important hundred and eighty one Ohio delegates could be the deciding factor..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A clerk placing a Morris sign in the store window. In the shop next door various TV's are in a window display. We s RACHEL MADDOW'S report on them.

dialogues.speaker: RACHEL MADDOW, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: And once again the old adage is true..."As goes Ohio, so goes the Nation."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Satellite trucks, press vehicles, police cars, etc At a catering truck, MOLLY STEARNS, a 19 year old intern grabs a tray of coffees and a box of doughnuts. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We stay on her as she runs across the street and through door...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MOLLY enters and we follow her through the campaign war r it's the size of a coffin, jammed to the hilt with twenty something staffers manning laptops. We're in the hustle and bustle of a live telecast. We see multiple angles of the telecast...

dialogues.speaker: SENATOR PULLMAN
dialogues.text: Would you call yourself a Christian?

dialogues.speaker: GOV. MORRIS
dialogues.text: How would that matter?

dialogues.speaker: SENATOR PULLMAN
dialogues.text: (Reading) "I have no idea what happens when we die, maybe nothing...maybe it was like before we were born." You did write this Governor...

dialogues.speaker: GOV. MORRIS
dialogues.text: Then let me try and clarify...I was raised Catholic, I am not a practicing Catholic...I have no idea what happens when you die and if the Senator does, then perhaps he should be President. I'll even vote for him. The audience laughs.

dialogues.speaker: SENATOR PULLMAN
dialogues.text: Is that your idea of being specific? MOLLY passes out coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're now live inside the debate. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GOV. MORRIS
dialogues.text: Let me be more specific. I am neither a Christian, nor an atheist, I'm not Jewish or Muslim...what I believe...my religion is written on a piece of parchment called the Constitution. Meaning I will defend, till my dying breath, your right to worship, in whatever God or lack thereof you believe in, as long as it doesn't hurt others. I believe we should be judged as a government by how we take care of those who can't take care of themselves. That's my religion. If you feel that I'm not religious enough, then don't vote for me. If you feel I'm not experienced enough or tall enough then don't vote for me. Because I'm not going to change those to get elected.

dialogues.speaker: SENATOR PULLMAN
dialogues.text: I just wanted you to say out loud if you believed in the teachings of the Bible.

dialogues.speaker: GOV. MORRIS
dialogues.text: Is this a Democratic primary or a general election? People laugh.

dialogues.speaker: SENATOR PULLMAN, (ON MONITOR)
dialogues.text: Well Governor, whoever wins this contest will be running for President...and if you don't think that these questions won't be central in a general election then you are living in fantasy land. I applaud your honesty Governor, I do...I'm simply pointing to what is obvious...we are running for President of the United States...not for student council president.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PAUL ZARA - Morris's campaign manager - is waiting in the wings off stage. STEPHEN sidles up next to him. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the background we can see the candidates shaking hands There is applause. PAUL is pushing fifty with the grizzled look of a hardene campaign veteran. He's Stephen's boss, the only guy betwe him and Governor Morris. Arms crossed, they watch their man on stage.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: A double?

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: A double.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Fucking national security. The GOVERNOR looks off stage to PAUL and STEPHEN for approval.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Outta the park.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: Home run. We hear the announcer thanking everyone for attending the debate. TOM DUFFY - campaign manager of the rival Pullman Campaig is also watching from the wings. Duffy's smooth, calculat and icy. He walks over to Stephen and Paul.

dialogues.speaker: DUFFY
dialogues.text: I'm trying to remember if the democrats ever nominated an atheist before...

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Well, we know they've nominated jackasses before.

dialogues.speaker: DUFFY
dialogues.text: (to Stephen) Must've been you that did the prep work. Paul's not that clever.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: You always had the brains Duffy, but me - I always had the balls. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DUFFY
dialogues.text: (nodding to Stephen) Looks like you got some brains now too. Be careful. I just might have to steal him from you. Duffy walks off to greet Senator Pullman as he makes his to the wings. Paul and Stephen eye him as he goes.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: What a prick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stephen, The mood singing. PAUL has Paul, Ida, and Ben are having drinks around a table. is festive. There is a piano player playing, a roll-away suitcase beside him.

dialogues.speaker: IDA
dialogues.text: So Paul, tell me something I don't know...tell me what's gonna happen on the 15th.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Ha-ha.

dialogues.speaker: IDA
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: What do you think Stevie?

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: It's ours for the taking.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Ben?

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: We'll win.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: What do you think Ida?

dialogues.speaker: IDA
dialogues.text: I'm asking you.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: You tell me and I'll tell you. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: IDA
dialogues.text: If had to say, I'd say it'll be close, but you'll eke it out.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Eke? To STEPHEN.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You see, she's trying to get under my skin.

dialogues.speaker: IDA
dialogues.text: So what's gonna happen?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Us by nine.

dialogues.speaker: IDA
dialogues.text: Nine? There's no way you'll win by nine.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: At least. Maybe more.

dialogues.speaker: IDA
dialogues.text: (To PAUL) So you're certain you're gonna win here?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Certain? No. Confident? Yes.

dialogues.speaker: IDA
dialogues.text: You just said you'll win by nine.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: And I think we will, but I won't tell you it's a sure thing. Fucking Saint Gabriel can blow his horn on election day and get his four horseman to rig the ballot boxes for Pullman and it wouldn't surprise me. Don't get me wrong. Six presidentials I've done and I've never felt this good. But am I gonna sit here and say "Yes -we will definitely win Ohio"? Not a chance. In the last thirty years seventy-three Democrats have run for president. How many have won? Three. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That means seventy guys ran who thought they had a chance, and they all lost.

dialogues.speaker: IDA
dialogues.text: So you're saying there's a good chance you won't win.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Don't twist my words. What I'm saying is that I'm not going to promise we'll win. But he's decorated by Bush Senior from the first Gulf war and protested the second. He left his state with a balanced budget and the fourth highest education rate. The Republicans have nobody out there that can touch this guy...so for this moment, this election, this primary is the presidential. And that Ida, is the state of the union. And on that note, I'm gonna take a shit. PAUL swigs down the rest of his drink and exits.

dialogues.speaker: IDA
dialogues.text: So Stephen...

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: Yes Ida?

dialogues.speaker: IDA
dialogues.text: Stephen, Stephen, Stephen....

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: Here it comes...hit me.

dialogues.speaker: IDA
dialogues.text: Paul's going to the airport?

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: IDA
dialogues.text: Getting on a plane.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: Mmhmm.

dialogues.speaker: IDA
dialogues.text: Where is that plane going? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: Three guesses.

dialogues.speaker: IDA
dialogues.text: Not going back to headquarters.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: Correct.

dialogues.speaker: IDA
dialogues.text: He's not going to Texas?

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: No need, we'll split Texas, it's a wash.

dialogues.speaker: IDA
dialogues.text: What if I said North Carolina?

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: That's your guess?

dialogues.speaker: IDA
dialogues.text: He's going to North Carolina.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: I will neither confirm nor deny that statement.

dialogues.speaker: IDA
dialogues.text: I knew it. Now tell me why.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: That I cannot do.

dialogues.speaker: IDA
dialogues.text: I hate you.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: You love me.

dialogues.speaker: IDA
dialogues.text: I love Paul. You I hate.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: You only love him because he gives you all the scoops.

dialogues.speaker: IDA
dialogues.text: Sexual favors?

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: You're engaged. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: IDA
dialogues.text: If it meant a good scoop my fiance would understand. IDA (CONTвЂ™D) You really buy into all this crap? All this take back the country nonsense?

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: Ida I'm not naive about this stuff. I've worked on more campaigns than most people do by the time they're forty...I'm telling you this is the one.

dialogues.speaker: IDA
dialogues.text: You really have drunk the kool-aid.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: I have drunk it it's delicious. I don't care whether he leads in the polls...I don't care whether he has all the tools...Because the truth is, he's the only one that's going to make a difference in peoples lives...Even the people that hate him. If Mike Morris is President it says more about us than it does about him. I don't give a fuck if he can win. He has to win.

dialogues.speaker: IDA
dialogues.text: Or what? The world will fall apart? It won't matter...Not one bit to the everyday lives of everyday fuckers who work and eat and sleep and get up and go back to work again. If your boy wins...You get a job in the white house...If he loses you're back at a consulting firm on K Street...That's it. You used to know that before you got all goosebumpy about this guy. Morris is a politician...He's a nice guy...They're all nice guys. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: IDA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He will let you down...sooner or later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: IDA and PAUL walk to Ida's car.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: This is off off off the record.

dialogues.speaker: IDA
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Franklin Thompson.

dialogues.speaker: IDA
dialogues.text: Seriously?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Off the record. The only people who know are the Governor, Stephen and me.

dialogues.speaker: IDA
dialogues.text: My lips are sealed.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I have a meeting tomorrow at Thompson's house.

dialogues.speaker: IDA
dialogues.text: He's gonna endorse?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: After I'm done talking with him, what do you think?

dialogues.speaker: IDA
dialogues.text: That's huge.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: It's more than huge. He has 356 pledged delegates...they all travel with him. That puts us over the top.

dialogues.speaker: IDA
dialogues.text: He's said publicly he's not gonna endorse anyone. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: That's what they all say until we get them alone in a room.

dialogues.speaker: IDA
dialogues.text: So this is for real?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Yup. It's just about in the bag.

dialogues.speaker: IDA
dialogues.text: When are you gonna announce?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Nope. That's all you get for now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Establishing shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben walks around to all the staffers, he hands out new ce phones.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Okay so listen up...these are your new cell phones...Shelly has pre- programmed everyone's numbers in...thank you Shelly...no personal calls...if you lose them, Paul has authorized me to kill you. Ben walks into Stephen's office and hands him his new pho

dialogues.speaker: BEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: New phones...

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: I'll get it ina bit... As Ben leaves, we see that Stephen is looking at early footage of Governor Morris. Another staffer and an editor are watching it with him. Outside the office we can see other staffers, through the glass partitions, running aro in campaign mode. We see some of the footage. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GOV MORRIS, (ON MONITOR)
dialogues.text: The economy...health care...I've got to believe we can do it. We have enemies...we have to understand why our enemies are our enemies, and see if there is something we can do about that besides using force. What we know from history is the answer to extremism is not extremism. Whoever is the next president, whoever steps up, has got a lot of work to do, but you have a little work to do yourself. Stephen hits pause.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: Fucking kill me...where did we get this?

dialogues.speaker: EDITOR
dialogues.text: Before he announced at a town hall meeting in Pennsylvania...

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: Thank God it wasn't overseas. Just get rid of it -

dialogues.speaker: EDITOR
dialogues.text: It plays to his base, if-

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: Are you fucking stoned...this is the same...the exact same piece the Republicans are gonna run against him in the general...we don't need to brag about it...Hi I'm Neville Chamberlain and I want to be your commander in chief.

dialogues.speaker: EDITOR
dialogues.text: If it's gonna come out-

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: It's gonna come out but not paid for by us pal. (To Staffer) Any truth on whether Pullman had investments in those diamond mines in Liberia? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: STAFFER 1
dialogues.text: We're still checking...it was a blog so who the fuck knows...

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: Doesn't matter I want to hear him denying it. If it's true, find out, if it's not, let them spend the next day telling the post that he doesn't own a diamond mine in Liberia...win win.

dialogues.speaker: STAFFER 1
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: We need to counter this Christian shit we're taking from last night...so get going...Where's our cut on the new thirty and a sixty second spots? We'll show it to him this afternoon in the staff meeting.

dialogues.speaker: EDITOR
dialogues.text: Got it. The Editor and staffer exit. Stephen turns to his computer and types as Molly walks in hands him some papers.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Ben wanted me to get you to sign off on this before the staff meeting.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: Oh, right. Thanks. I've been waiting for this.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Anything interesting?

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: Just some white paper I gotta pass out tonight.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: White paper? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: Negative shit. Our oppo guys do research - we feed it to the press, hope they bite.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: So like what sort of negative stuff?

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: Read tomorrow's paper and you'll see.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Which paper?

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: All of them.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: So it's something big?

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: I wish it were something bigger actually. Just some transportation numbers. I'll have to spin this shit pretty heavy if we want it to stick.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Well that's what you're good at, right?

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: I guess.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: (Holding up her phone) Did you get your phone?

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: (Holds his up) Just now.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: (Mock serious) It's exciting isn't it? He looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: You a Bearcat...? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She starts 18. (4)

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: A what?

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: A Cincinnati Bearcat?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Oh no...I'm not from here...I worked with you in Iowa actually.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: Oh that's right...but you changed something. (Searching for a way out.)

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: My hair?

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: You changed your hair.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: (Enjoying this) No..

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: I must look like a total dumb ass right now.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Not at all...you're the big man on campus...I'm just a lowly intern.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: Come on it's not like that.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Sure it is...you get to stay at the Millennium, they put us into a motel on the other side of the river.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: You're right, I am big man on campus.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Now you're starting to see. to leave.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We do have the better bar though. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: I heard that.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: You ought to stop by one night and have a drink with the worker bees.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: Maybe I will...when's a good night?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Tonight's good...

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: Really? Tuesday?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Yeah it's quiet.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: Quiet's good.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Well you have my number.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: I do?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Programmed right there in your phone.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: Oh...right...(He opens the phone)

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Under Mary.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: (Looking at the phone) Yup...Mary. Molly laughs. Then, as she exits:

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Molly...my name's Molly... Stephen smiles to himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We follow a housekeeper down the hallway and into the liv room where we see Paul sitting with, Senator Thompson.

dialogues.speaker: SENATOR THOMPSON
dialogues.text: That's what I'm hearing...since Super Tuesday I'm a very popular guy. What are your polls telling you?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: That Pullman's negatives are high...mid forties. Senator we have an open seat in the White House and the Republicans don't have dick. They're disorganized and they can't find a nominee that isn't a world class fuck up. They look like Democrats. No Republican is gonna show up to vote for their guy. But if Pullman gets the Democratic nod they'll show up to vote against him.

dialogues.speaker: SENATOR THOMPSON
dialogues.text: And so you think they won't for your guy...you think Morris gets into the independents?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I sure do. Senator...I'ma bit confused...we need your delegates...we need you...your fund raising. It was my understanding that...your endorsement a week before Ohio...would win this for us...

dialogues.speaker: SENATOR THOMPSON
dialogues.text: (Looks to his aide) Estella...hand me that ice bucket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're in a staff meeting with the brain trust. Paul's gon but the rest are there...STEPHEN, BEN, GOVERNOR MORRIS. MOLLY is running in and out, she gets glances from all th guys. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: Paul knows...Paul agrees...

dialogues.speaker: GOV. MORRIS
dialogues.text: Ben, where's my op ed on national service? It's better for me to work off of that.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Got it right here. (He opens his laptop. )

dialogues.speaker: GOV. MORRIS
dialogues.text: Get me a hard copy...I hate these fucking things...

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: Print it out.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: I'll get it printed. Molly, I'm printing out this op ed...can you grab it off the printer?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Be right back.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: Governor...if you want to change...or lets call it refresh...

dialogues.speaker: GOV. MORRIS
dialogues.text: Just give me a second...

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: National service isn't polling like the rest of your domestic policy.

dialogues.speaker: GOV. MORRIS
dialogues.text: I don't give a shit about polling...I'm not going to play this game with you Stephen...and if this is your good cop bad cop act with Paul...

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: Good cop, good cop.

dialogues.speaker: GOV. MORRIS
dialogues.text: I'm not changing it. MOLLY returns and hands the Governor a copy. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GOV. MORRIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hang on. He reads down until he finds what he's looking for.

dialogues.speaker: GOV. MORRIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Yeah I said it all here, "It's going to help people get an education...it's going to create national unity...it's going to teach young people a trade...and it's going to help get people out of debt from college loans. Tell me where that fails.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: All of that is exactly right...Governor if you're going to do it...then do it. Don't make it voluntary...mandatory.

dialogues.speaker: GOV. MORRIS
dialogues.text: That'll poll well.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: Mandatory!...everyone who graduates high school or turns eighteen, gives two years to his or her country. Military...peace corps...plant fucking trees, I don't care...and for that...their college education is paid for...period.

dialogues.speaker: GOV. MORRIS
dialogues.text: We do all of that now, with this...

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: No sir you don't...do it all...all the way. Mandatory.

dialogues.speaker: GOV. MORRIS
dialogues.text: Paul likes this?...you guys are my brain trust.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: And here's the beauty of it...everyone who is older than eighteen and past the age of eligibility, would be for it...create national pride...give all the kids an education. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GOV. MORRIS
dialogues.text: And all the others?

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: Can't vote. Too young. This sits with them. Some start to smile.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You can't lose. MOLLY enters.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Stephen you have a call on three, your dad.

dialogues.speaker: GOV. MORRIS
dialogues.text: Okay, you and Ben work it into the stump speech - get me a hard copy and I'll write it in my own words.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: Remember, Governor... you have a six o'clock with Charlie Rose...

dialogues.speaker: GOV. MORRIS
dialogues.text: Why am I doing him?

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: It's long form... he's flying in...

dialogues.speaker: GOV. MORRIS
dialogues.text: Is Paul going?

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: No, he won't be back... Ben and I are taking you... He exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STEPHEN picks up the receiver and pushes line three.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: .--Don't tell me anyone's died...

dialogues.speaker: DUFFY
dialogues.text: Hey Stephen... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: Who is this?

dialogues.speaker: DUFFY
dialogues.text: Tom Duffy...sorry about the dad bit...but I didn't think you'd want my name yelled out at a Morris campaign office. STEPHEN gets up and closes the door.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: DUFFY
dialogues.text: You got a couple of minutes...I'd like to sit down with you.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: What for?

dialogues.speaker: DUFFY
dialogues.text: I think it's important.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: If it's important shouldn't you be calling Paul?

dialogues.speaker: DUFFY
dialogues.text: I'm calling you...This is all on the up and up...just give me five minutes.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: I can't be talking to you...

dialogues.speaker: DUFFY
dialogues.text: I hear you...but if you get five minutes...I'll be at the Heads First Sports Bar for the next couple of hours.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: I can't Tom.

dialogues.speaker: DUFFY
dialogues.text: There won't be anybody there...if you get a chance there's something I want to show you. DUFFY hangs up. STEPHEN sits for a few beats. his cell phone and dials...it goes straight to voice mail 24. He picks up (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: Paul, listen, call me as soon as you can...it's important. STEPHEN hangs up the phone and we stay with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BAR -вЂ” LATER STEPHEN sits in the car, he watches the door of the bar making sure no one is around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're in a run-down bar in Cincinnati. The furniture is shabby - Formica tables, cheap metal framed chairs. The p is desolate except for TOM and STEPHEN who sit at the bar

dialogues.speaker: DUFFY
dialogues.text: You're working for the wrong man.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: You're working for the wrong man.

dialogues.speaker: DUFFY
dialogues.text: Oh on the contrary you are working for the wrong man. You've got something the other guys don't have.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: DUFFY
dialogues.text: Yeah, what is it exactly? Charm isn't the right word. It's more than that. You exude something. You draw people in. All the reporters love you. Even the ones that hate you love you. You play them all like they're pieces on a chess board. And you make it look effortless. We both know how much work it takes, constantly being on guard, weighing every word so carefully, every move. But from the outside, you make it look easy. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beat. 26.

dialogues.speaker: DUFFY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: People are scared of you because they don't understand how you do it, and they love you for it. There's nothing more valuable in this business - the ability to win people's respect by making them mistake their fear for love. You can guess what I'm gonna say next.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: No...I don't think I can.

dialogues.speaker: DUFFY
dialogues.text: I want you to work for us.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: You gotta be kidding me.

dialogues.speaker: DUFFY
dialogues.text: Not in the least. You are going to lose Ohio.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: I am not.

dialogues.speaker: DUFFY
dialogues.text: You're sitting on about a six percent lead in both polls...six percent of the Democrats polled.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: Eight.

dialogues.speaker: DUFFY
dialogues.text: Six...but that doesn't matter...Independents and Republicans can vote for the Democratic candidate.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: You think they like your guy?...pro choice...tax and spend liberal? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DUFFY
dialogues.text: Fuck no they hate him...they think they can beat my guy...but they're worried about yours...so starting tomorrow morning you're gonna see a fucking blitz...Rush Limbaugh, Sean Hannity, all the right wing blogs are gonna start a "Get out the vote campaign"...it's already started...every fucking conservative in Ohio is gonna stand in line and punch my guys ticket...that's just one of the steps...Ohio is gone...the polls don't mean shit...tomorrow morning everyone will know...that's why I want you to handle the fallout we'll take in the press... They look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: DUFFY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And by the way...we've got Thompson in the bag.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: I know for a fact that Thompson is going with us.

dialogues.speaker: DUFFY
dialogues.text: We promised him Secretary of State, Ohio is over...it's been over for weeks...and with Thompson's delegates...I'm thinking down the road now...that's why I want you...I'll bring you in straight at the top.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: I can't do it.

dialogues.speaker: DUFFY
dialogues.text: I'm not asking for an answer right this moment.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: I've played dirty but I don't have to play dirty anymore...you know why? Cause I got Morris! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DUFFY
dialogues.text: None of this is about the democratic process Steve, It's about getting your guy into office. Simple as that.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: This is the sort of shit the Republicans pull.

dialogues.speaker: DUFFY
dialogues.text: You're right, this is exactly what the Republicans do, and it's about time we learned from them. They're meaner, tougher and more disciplined than we are. I've been in this business for twenty five years and I've seen way too many Democrats bite the dust because they wouldn't get down in the mud with the fucking elephants.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: Paul's a friend.

dialogues.speaker: DUFFY
dialogues.text: Do you want to work for a friend or do you want to work for the President? Think about it...you have my number. Duffy gets up and leaves.

dialogues.speaker: RESIDENTIAL STREET
dialogues.text: STEPHEN walks to his car. He dials PAUL on his phone. Pau is in North Carolina driving. We intercut.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: Paul.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: They don't make quaaludes any more do they?

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: Not that I know of. What's going on with Thompson? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: He wants something but we'll be fine... So what's so important?

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: It's nothing...never mind.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Allright...I'm on the cell if you need me. I fly to DC tomorrow and back tomorrow night.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: Yeah okay...I'll look for quaaludes.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Good man. STEPHEN ends the call. He stands in silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're in the bathroom of a hotel room. GOVERNOR MORRIS is being made up for the Charlie Rose Show. A SECRET SERVICE AGENT stands in the adjoining room. The GOVERNOR talks to the MAKE-UP LADY while STEPHEN and BEN stand in the adjoi room as well.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: (to Ben) Just get online and see if there's any chatter on the blogs...

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: What kind of chatter? There's always chatter.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: I don't know... just see what they're talking about.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Give me a second... He sets his laptop down and starts typing. The Governor, who's been talking the whole time, yells ou through the door. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GOV. MORRIS
dialogues.text: Stephen... you're still single, right?

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: I'm married to the campaign, Governor.

dialogues.speaker: GOV. MORRIS
dialogues.text: Good answer. (to the make-up girl) He's married to the campaign...

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: (looking at his computer) Wall Street Journal poll has our numbers holding steady and Pullman dropped a point.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: Really? When did they do that? Governor... Wall Street Journal numbers are in... and Pullman's down a point.

dialogues.speaker: GOV. MORRIS
dialogues.text: Now we're moving in the right direction. Ben, are you still single?

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: I'm married to the campaign, Governor.

dialogues.speaker: GOV. MORRIS
dialogues.text: (to the make-up girl) Crack team. The GOVERNOR starts to sing "The Best Is Yet To Come".

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: (to Ben) Make sure Charlie Rose has these latest numbers before he goes on...

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: (jumps up) I'm on it. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: And get a copy of the show before we leave...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room has been transformed into an interview space. On air- CHARLIE ROSE and GOV. MORRIS mid-interview...

dialogues.speaker: GOV. MORRIS
dialogues.text: Is it a difficult decision? I would have to believe that it is... would I do it? No... but I can't see myself... or anyone... certainly not a government, telling a woman what she can do with her body.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE ROSE
dialogues.text: So you would appoint a judge to...

dialogues.speaker: GOV. MORRIS
dialogues.text: В«+. I would consider it arrogant to judge someone until I've walked in their shoes.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE ROSE
dialogues.text: But you're against the death penalty?

dialogues.speaker: GOV. MORRIS
dialogues.text: Yes. Because of what it says about us as a society.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE ROSE
dialogues.text: Suppose Governor it was your wife...

dialogues.speaker: GOV. MORRIS
dialogues.text: And she was murdered, what would I do.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE ROSE
dialogues.text: It gets more complicated when it's personal. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GOV. MORRIS
dialogues.text: Sure...well if I could get to him I'd find a way to kill him.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE ROSE
dialogues.text: So you, you Governor would impose the death penalty.

dialogues.speaker: GOV. MORRIS
dialogues.text: No, I would commit a crime for which I would happily go to jail.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE ROSE
dialogues.text: Then why not let society do that?

dialogues.speaker: GOV. MORRIS
dialogues.text: Because society has to be better than the individual. If I were to do that I would be wrong.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE ROSE
dialogues.text: And what about guns?

dialogues.speaker: GOV. MORRIS
dialogues.text: Isn't it time for a commercial. They laugh.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE ROSE
dialogues.text: This is public TV, we don't have commercials...

dialogues.speaker: GOV. MORRIS
dialogues.text: That's unfortunate.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. MOTEL вЂ”- KENTUCKY - NIGHT We're in Kentucky, just over the Ohio River from Cincinna This is where all the interns stay. In the hotel bar, Stephen and Molly are sitting at a back table, they've both been drinking hard.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: Where'd you go after Iowa?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: California for Super Tuesday.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: I had to go to New York. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beat. 33.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: I know...you guys needed a lot more help over there.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: Yeah. So why politics?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Because the pay is so good.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: It just seems like an odd fit.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: My dad is Jack Stearns.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: He's a good guy.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: He's an asshole but he's your boss.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: He's not my boss. He's the head of the DNC.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: You don't work for the Democratic National Committee?

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: I work for Paul, Paul works for Morris and if Morris wins, he's going to be your dad's boss.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Don't tell my dad that.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: Don't tell your dad a lot of things.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Never.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: What time do you start tomorrow? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Nine AM...I'm showing the new interns how to robo call...you see...I'm the experienced intern.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: I do see...

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: How old are you?

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: How old do you think I am?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Thirty?

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: You think I'm thirty?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, how old are you?

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: Thirty...how old are you?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: How old do you think I am?

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: Twenty one?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Twenty.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: That's young.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Too young to fuck a thirty year old?

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: See laws are different in different states. Here in your hotel, in Kentucky...it's frowned upon...but we'll go across the bridge into Ohio...

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Where your hotel is? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: Yeah surprisingly they're very lax about their child endangerment laws...

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: You have a car? I don't drive.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: I took a cab.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: I have the keys to the campaign bus... On their smiles

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Morris campaign bus is parked badly, a tire up on the curb in front of the hotel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STEPHEN is on his cell phone, he paces back and forth in front of the TV - A news show in on. MOLLY is in bed - sheets pulled up around her, she's just waking up.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS MATTHEWS, (ON TV)
dialogues.text: In fairness, this has been tried before...Operation Chaos, as Rush Limbaugh called it, where Republicans voted for a Democrat they thought they could beat in the general election. We asked Senator Pullman's campaign manager if this sudden right wing support is welcome... Cut to a pre-tape with DUFFY. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DUFFY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Is it decisive?...Of Course not...look, we believe that the polls are within the margin of error and that the Senator will win Ohio...with Ohio Democrats...I can't really see Republicans showing up to vote for our candidate...having said that, we'll take all the support we can get.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: (On the phone) What time does Paul land?... Christ...who do we talk to about polling?...no...I just...I just need to get some internal polling on the fucking Independents and the right-wing nuts.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Do you want me to go? He gestures for her to wait.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: Listen, put me on the line with...what's the guy's name at the Wall Street Journal?... yeah...

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: You seem busy...I should go. He whispers to her.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: Wait. Back to phone.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Right...Adler...get me on the line with him.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Steve? She starts to get dressed.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: Molly listen, just give me a second...I want to talk to you about something. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: We can talk about it later if... Stephen holds his finger up.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: (Into phone) What? No nobody...just the cleaning lady...listen Ben...keep trying till you get him. We're gonna go with the position that we've always said, the race is closer than the polling...right...no don't...don't say that...just get him on the line and call me...I'll handle it...yup. He hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Sorry about that.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: The cleaning lady.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: You called me the cleaning lady.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: You're not mad about that are you?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: No why would I be mad? Beat. MOLLY looks at the TV. MOLLY (CONTвЂ™D) Look. STEPHEN'S eyes go to the TV where CHRIS is still talking.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS MATHEWS
dialogues.text: Earlier I spoke with Jack Stearns, head of the DNC, and he had this to say... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JACK STEARNS
dialogues.text: I know you're looking for a reaction, but listen we have two great candidates in a very tight race...and at the end of the day the voters will decide who best can represent this party in the fall.

dialogues.speaker: CHRIS MATHEWS
dialogues.text: I understand Jack - but doesn't this kind of disruption take away from what you want to be pushing this year? Back to STEPHEN

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: Your dad is an asshole.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: I'll tell him you said that.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: Do that.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: You said you wanted to talk to me about something?

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: Yeah, I just wanted...I just wanted to be clear about everything...so there's no confusion...

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: I won't tell anyone about last night.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: Well yeah, I'd appreciate it if we kept this...I mean, you know how people are.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Really wouldn't look good if you screwed an intern.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: It's not like I got drunk and this happened...I mean...I wanted to...I really like you...you're smart...but I just...I don't want there to be any expectations... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Steven, you don't have to say anything.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: I just don't want you to think I'm some kind of player.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Well you are kind of a player, but that's okay.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: No I'm not. I was being polite. MOLLY starts to tie STEPHENS tie.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Bullshit...you were trying to pick me up.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: No I wasn't.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: You were pretty obvious about it.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: I was?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Totally.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: I thought I was being all smooth and subtle.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: You were pretty forward.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: You were pretty forward ...inviting me to the bar.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Well...I've been trying to fuck you for a while.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: Wow.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Pretty slutty of me, huh? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: No, not at all...I mean I kind of respect it in a weird sort of way.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Good.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: You have absolutely no idea how to tie a tie do you...

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: No no not a clue.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: You're very mature.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: For a teenager. Molly kisses him and exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We Intercut with PAUL driving. STEPHEN walks towards a private jet, the GOVERNOR is at t plane talking to some aides.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: When are you coming back?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I'll be at the event...a little late...these cock suckers...fucking dirty shit.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: What happened with Thompson?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Nothing, the prick...we had him all sewed up...MOTHER FUCKER...how bad is it?

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: I'm running some numbers now...I don't know... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Alright, I'll be there in three hours...I want hard numbers...and a strategy.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: Yeah I'm on it...I gotta go. He hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The GOVERNOR and STEPHEN are flying through a bad storm, plane is getting knocked all around. Also on Board are BE and a SECRET SERVICE AGENT. Stephen is holding onto the armrests, white knuckling it, the Governor watches him.

dialogues.speaker: GOV. MORRIS
dialogues.text: You okay?

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: Yup...(Nope) Just trying to figure out our stops on the ground.

dialogues.speaker: GOV. MORRIS
dialogues.text: I think the weather might determine that. If we get there. Both men sit with their heads back on the headrests.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: We'll be fine...we have to do it...and it's the right thing. Nothing bad happens when it's the right thing.

dialogues.speaker: GOV. MORRIS
dialogues.text: Is this your personal theory...cause I can shoot holes in it...Roberto Clemente...on a humanitarian flight.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: Well there are exceptions to every rule... They smile. The Governor looks at Stephen.

dialogues.speaker: GOV. MORRIS
dialogues.text: So how we doin?

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: Fine now. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GOV. MORRIS
dialogues.text: No I mean...the campaign how we doin?

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: Great...

dialogues.speaker: GOV. MORRIS
dialogues.text: Listen Stephen...you're not Paul. I pay him to use the word "great". I pay you to tell me the truth.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: I think we're solid.

dialogues.speaker: GOV. MORRIS
dialogues.text: Okay Paul.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: Governor there's a big difference between Paul and me. Paul only believes in winning so he'll do or say anything to win.

dialogues.speaker: GOV. MORRIS
dialogues.text: But you wouldn't.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: I'll do or say anything if I believe in it...but I have to believe in the cause.

dialogues.speaker: GOV. MORRIS
dialogues.text: You'll make a lousy consultant when you're out of this line of work.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: Well I won't be out of this line of work as long as you're in it.

dialogues.speaker: GOV. MORRIS
dialogues.text: So at best you've got eight years...then you'll end up with a nice little consultant firm on Farragut North...eating at the Palm...pulling in seven hundred and fifty grand a year...pimping out Senators to Saudi Princes. They both smile.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: Pimping out ex presidents... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GOV. MORRIS
dialogues.text: Then I better win...

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're in in front standing daughter

dialogues.speaker: GOVERNOR
dialogues.text: a large hall. GOVERNOR MORRIS is on stage, he stands of a huge American flag. Morris's wife CINDY is in the wings along with their seven year old BETH. MORRIS addresses the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: GOV. MORRIS
dialogues.text: Now, I've been married for eleven years, to the smartest person I know...and we have a normal marriage...which means when we disagree...she wins. What we don't ever disagree on is how we're going to leave this planet for our daughter. Are we gonna leave it better off, or worse? The richest people in this country don't pay their fare share. And when they're asked to, they cry socialism, they use phrases like redistribution of wealth. That scares everybody and they all run and they hide. For the record, my campaign is vehemently against the distribution of wealth to the richest Americans, by our government! And I will run on that!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PAUL and STEPHEN are back stage behind the huge American flag. We can hear the Governor's speech in the B.G.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: I didn't think it was true.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Whoa...

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: But I should have told you this yesterday...sorry... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: -Slow down.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: I met with Tom Duffy yesterday.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: You were on a plane and he called me and he asked if we could meet...And I said why...he said it was very important so I did...but I should've fucking told you...

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Stop Stop let me get this straight. You met with Tom Duffy?

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: What'd he want Stephen?

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: -the gist of it is he wants to hire me. He wants me to jump ship and come work for him...this is bad Paul. He showed me poll numbers with Pullman ahead by four. We're in really deep fucking trouble he laid out their whole plan. Robo- calls, traffic jams, fake lit, and fucking Thompson. They promised him Secretary of State.

dialogues.speaker: GOV. MORRIS
dialogues.text: You know how you fight the war on terror?...Don't need their product anymore. Their product is oil, just don't need it and they go away. We don't have to bomb anyone we don't have to invade anyone!

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: If this is some sort of practical-I mean -my fucking blood pressure is going through the roof right now.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: Paul I'm sorry. Believe me...I just didn't think it was true.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: It doesn't fucking matter what you thought. It matters what you did. It matters what you didn't do. If all this shit is true I made a fucking ass of myself at Thompson's place. And I gave away our game plan.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: Please believe me that I honestly believed you were gonna come back and you were gonna tell me that we have Thompson in the bag and I didn't see the point. But it doesn't make it right and I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Let me think...let me think...

dialogues.speaker: GOV. MORRIS
dialogues.text: If I'm your president, the first thing I put in motion, ten years from the day I'm in office...no new car in America runs on an internal combustion engine. It'll create hundreds of thousands of new jobs...we will start the next technological revolution and we will lead the world again...like we used to...

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: We get the Governor right after he finishes singing Kum Bay Ya and give him everything we know.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: Who do you want...

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: You, me and the Governor, that's it! What's he got after?

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: A fund-raiser in Cleveland tonight.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: He'll be late...we're gonna tell him that if he doesn't offer Thompson a cabinet position...he's not gonna get the nomination.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: Will he go for it?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I don't fucking know Stephen. As Paul exits he shoots back.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Find us a room...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MOLLY walks up the steps of the auditorium into the lobby staffer hands her some papers and she continues. We pull down a corridor and land at a rehearsal room door. She ha the papers to BEN. The Governor's wife CINDY, daughter BETH and a security m are waiting outside the door.

dialogues.speaker: GOV. MORRIS
dialogues.text: How real are the numbers? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: We might pick up a couple of points...but we're...I don't know, we lose by three or four percent.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Who the fuck knows Governor...but we can't take the chance...

dialogues.speaker: GOV. MORRIS
dialogues.text: What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I think we fold up the campaign in Ohio...take a loss and blame it on the Republican's playing games...head to North Carolina.

dialogues.speaker: GOV. MORRIS
dialogues.text: I can't run from Ohio...they'1ll kill us.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Not if you get Thompson's endorsement.

dialogues.speaker: GOV. MORRIS
dialogues.text: I'm not gonna do it. What's he want head of the FDA or something ridiculous?

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: Cabinet post.

dialogues.speaker: GOV. MORRIS
dialogues.text: Labor?

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: State... This sits with them.

dialogues.speaker: GOV. MORRIS
dialogues.text: Are you fucking kidding me...I'm gonna give Secretary of State to a guy who wants to cut the top ten floors off the UN? Paul when we started this campaign I said I wasn't gonna make those kind of deals. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Governor, if you lose Ohio, and they get Thompson's delegates...Then they get North Carolina...then they get the lead. A lead you can't beat. But if we walk from Ohio, take Thompson, give him a cabinet post, then we take North Carolina. His state. Then Pennsylvania. Your state. And then it's simple math Mike. Take his endorsement and the race is over.

dialogues.speaker: GOV. MORRIS
dialogues.text: Paul, I respect you...respect your opinion...but I'm never gonna do it...so I suggest we find a way for me to win Ohio. They sit there looking at their shoes.

dialogues.speaker: GOV. MORRIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Anything else? Off their looks we-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're mid action. Everyone is there. Phones...emails...people running in and out. STEPHEN, BEN MOLLY...sleeves rolled up. PAUL is in a closed room but w can see him on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: (On the phone) Do we have any other senators that can go to bat for us? House members won't do.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: (Whispering to him) Or a Congressman from Ohio maybe.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: Right...but we need a Senator...one from Ohio would be nice. We push the camera through the room, edging closer to PAU (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: (To Stephen) This is all the car rental companies in Northern Ohio...they've booked every single van for Tuesday...

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: Fuck...Jess, I'll call you back... (To Molly) All of them? Goddamit!

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: (On the computer) Here's what I have so far...Independents don't seem to be biting, but Republicans are...or say they are.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: They're not gonna tell a pollster that they're gonna vote Democratic...I don't even know how to read these polls.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: I called and we can get a hundred vans out of Covington and Newport Kentucky.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: We don't need the fucking vans...we just don't want Pullman to have them... We keep pushing in on PAUL until we can hear him talking reporter on the phone. - During this conversation he type his laptop.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: No, No that's not what I'm saying...we were the underdog before we got into this and we continue to be the underdog...well the numbers...we knew the numbers would get closer the closer we got to Tuesday...I'm not lowering expectations...have you ever heard me say that we had Ohio locked?... Then at least give me the courtesy of printing that in your column.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see The SUV drive down the highway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're in the second row of seats of the Governor's SUV. CINDY'S head on his shoulder. They are very comfortable a easy with each other. The Governor is writing a speech on legal pad.

dialogues.speaker: CINDY
dialogues.text: What're you writing?

dialogues.speaker: GOV. MORRIS
dialogues.text: The greatest speech ever given on hydrogen power.

dialogues.speaker: CINDY
dialogues.text: The bar is awfully high on that one.

dialogues.speaker: GOV. MORRIS
dialogues.text: Don't I know it.

dialogues.speaker: CINDY
dialogues.text: I got hit up by Mitchell's wife for you to show up at her "Daughters of the American Revolution" luncheon.

dialogues.speaker: GOV. MORRIS
dialogues.text: Who's Mitchell?

dialogues.speaker: CINDY
dialogues.text: Congressman from the first district. You might want to remember that.

dialogues.speaker: GOV. MORRIS
dialogues.text: Fucking Congressmen. Could you imagine doing this every two years?

dialogues.speaker: CINDY
dialogues.text: No I can't. Lets just do this one more time.

dialogues.speaker: GOV. MORRIS
dialogues.text: In four more years.

dialogues.speaker: CINDY
dialogues.text: That's it. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beat Beat. Beat. 51.

dialogues.speaker: GOV. MORRIS
dialogues.text: Deal.

dialogues.speaker: CINDY
dialogues.text: You think we'll lose Ohio?

dialogues.speaker: GOV. MORRIS
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: CINDY
dialogues.text: If you took Thompson's delegates the race is over. Ohio wouldn't matter.

dialogues.speaker: GOV. MORRIS
dialogues.text: Is Paul working on you?

dialogues.speaker: CINDY
dialogues.text: (Shaking her head) Stephen.

dialogues.speaker: GOV. MORRIS
dialogues.text: (Smiling) They are good.

dialogues.speaker: CINDY
dialogues.text: Is Thompson so bad?

dialogues.speaker: GOV. MORRIS
dialogues.text: He's a shit.

dialogues.speaker: CINDY
dialogues.text: Worse than Pullman?

dialogues.speaker: GOV. MORRIS
dialogues.text: Yes Stephen.

dialogues.speaker: GOV. MORRIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Every time I draw a line in the sand...and I keep moving it. Fund raising, union deals...I wasn't going to do any of it...negative ads...I can't on this one. Not Thompson. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GOV. MORRIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Tell Mrs. Mitchell I'll make her goddamn luncheon. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: GOV. MORRIS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Let the old ladies pat me on the head. They smile.

dialogues.speaker: CINDY
dialogues.text: You've got great hair.

dialogues.speaker: GOV. MORRIS
dialogues.text: You too baby. They lay their heads back onto the headrests.

dialogues.speaker: A BIT LATER
dialogues.text: A few hundred students sit around The GOVERNOR in a theat as he fields questions. MORRIS is cornered by a conservative student.

dialogues.speaker: STUDENT 1
dialogues.text: Gay marriage?

dialogues.speaker: GOV. MORRIS
dialogues.text: It's a silly argument.

dialogues.speaker: STUDENT 1
dialogues.text: Not to fifty percent of Americans.

dialogues.speaker: GOV. MORRIS
dialogues.text: Over the age of fifty.

dialogues.speaker: STUDENT 1
dialogues.text: That's who votes...that's who shows up at the polls.

dialogues.speaker: GOV. MORRIS
dialogues.text: Well that's changing...and hopefully the way we frame the argument is... At this point the camera travels backstage to find STEPHE BEN, PAUL and MOLLY working the phones and laptops. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (To Stephen) Keep an eye on the Governor.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: (To BEN) Let me know how it's going out there.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm on it. BEN takes us back out, and under this we hear the GOVERNO continue debating...

dialogues.speaker: STUDENT 1
dialogues.text: From...a religious...a

dialogues.speaker: GOV. MORRIS
dialogues.text: From a religious to a civil rights issue.

dialogues.speaker: STUDENT 1
dialogues.text: But one could argue a great difference between gender and race.

dialogues.speaker: GOV. MORRIS
dialogues.text: Not really. They used to ban interracial marriage. ..women couldn't vote...the list goes on...

dialogues.speaker: STUDENT 1
dialogues.text: The argument of course- We hear boos from students in the audience. At this point the camera finds MORRIS. Morris quiets the students.

dialogues.speaker: GOV. MORRIS
dialogues.text: Now wait she has a point to make....

dialogues.speaker: STUDENT 1
dialogues.text: The argument is that men and women, can in fact be separate but equal, races cannot.

dialogues.speaker: GOV. MORRIS
dialogues.text: How so? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: STUDENT 1
dialogues.text: You have separate public bathrooms for men and women but it would be illegal to have separate bathrooms for two races.

dialogues.speaker: GOV. MORRIS
dialogues.text: Now.

dialogues.speaker: STUDENT 1
dialogues.text: (Laughing) Yes now. Audience laughs.

dialogues.speaker: GOV. MORRIS
dialogues.text: So that's what I'm saying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STEPHEN, BEN and the rest, head out of the town hall to g on the bus.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: What time is this on tonight?

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Nine o'clock.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: How'd he do?

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: He did good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bus rolls down the highway

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a flurry of activity. STEPHEN, BEN, MOLLY and our REGULAR STAFFERS...are all on phones, Blackberry's and laptop's. MOLLY looks back over her shoulder to STEPHEN, who's face is lit by his laptop. He looks up...they lock eyes.  55.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're tight on a TV. It's the taped broadcast of the prev town hall meeting. As the scene plays we pull back to see STEPHEN and MOLLY making love. We see pieces of body part Hands...a leg...hair being pulled...it's what we've grown used to seeing in a seventies love scene, all lit by the flickering of a television. The only score we hear is the sound of the TV.

dialogues.speaker: GOV. MORRIS
dialogues.text: See we're framing the argument based on the idea that homosexuality is a choice, you choose to be gay, not that you were born that way like being born black. Because if you start the discussion with the idea that gay is not a life choice but part of your DNA, then gay marriage is and can only be a civil rights issue. ANOTHER STUDENT steps up to the microphone.

dialogues.speaker: STUDENT 2
dialogues.text: Do you think candor is your appeal? Is that what you're running on as much as your platform...?

dialogues.speaker: GOV. MORRIS
dialogues.text: We'll see. It'll drive them to the polls one way or the other.

dialogues.speaker: STUDENT 2
dialogues.text: I just heard a lot of Christian Coalition cars start up. We pull focus now onto STEPHEN and MOLLY. STEPHEN on top not moving. He looks down to the area where an erection would normall at this time...then he looks back to Molly.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: It's not you. They laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stephen is lying in bed working on some papers. Molly is asleep next to him. Stephen's cell phone rings.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: Hello... Almost at the same time we hear another man's voice on th phone.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: Molly? They both stop. No one speaks. Stephen is about to speak again when the caller hangs up. Stephen looks at the phone...he then looks to the bedside table where he sees identical phone. His phone. He's picked up Molly's phone mistake. He looks at the name of the incoming call...ther is none...he looks at the caller ID number...he looks at clock...2:30 AM.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: Your phone rang.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: Who's calling at 2:30 in the morning?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: I don't know?

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: He asked for you by name.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: You answered it?

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: I thought it was mine. Who was it?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: I don't know...

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: One of the other interns drunk dialing you? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: (Kidding) Oh that never happens...let me see the number... She reaches for the phone, but Steven keeps it away from

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: Hold on...

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: (Still waiting for it) Stephen...

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: I'm gonna call him back. He pushes the redial button.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: .В»-And I'm gonna tell him that I'm your dad...

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Gimme my phone Stephen!

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: And I'm gonna tell him I'm coming over there with a shotgun...

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: (Getting more urgent) Don't do that Stephen... Hang up! Stephen, listens to the outgoing message, while he looks Molly...her eyes starting to well up. We hear the buzzing of the message through the phone. The we see Stephens reaction as it begins to dawn on him who listening to. He closes the phone without leaving a message. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: Why is the Governor calling you at 2:30 in the morning? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Why is the Governor calling you at all?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: I'm in trouble...

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: With the Governor? What's going on?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: I was working on the campaign in Iowa...we had a party in Ben's room after the rally in Des Moines...

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: There was a party with you...and Ben...and the Governor.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: No he wasn't there.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: Where was he?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: I took him up a hard copy of the polling numbers...

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: After the party?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: (Shaking her head yes) About midnight I guess...I stood in the doorway with him...we were talking...a long time...then he just reached behind me and closed the door.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: Jesus fucking Christ...Were you drunk?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Not that drunk...

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: How many times? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Just that once.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: Does anybody know? Did anyone see you?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: How could you know?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: I know!

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: Then why is he calling you now?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: I called him first.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Because I didn't know who to go to...and I needed nine hundred bucks...

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: For what?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: I can't go to my dad...We're catholic. MOLLY (CONTвЂ™D) So what should I do? A long beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're close on STEPHEN as he walks down the sidewalk and into...  60.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STEPHEN walks into the campaign office. He looks at all t posters with pictures of Morris. People greet him as he walks past. The signs all look wrong now. The smile on Morris's face looks fake. He sees MOLLY as he passes and heads into the war room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STEPHEN is going through the drawers in his desk... he go to the office door, opens it and yells to Ben in the bull

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: Ben... come here a minute BEN stops what he's doing and heads into Stephen's office

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: What's up?

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: What's our limit on petty cash?

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: It's probably five hundred. Why?

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: I need as much as we have.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Everything okay?... anything I can help with?

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: Yeah...don't put it on the books. That's all.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: What should I put it down as?

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: Don't put it down as anything...

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Anything over a hundred I got to put it down as something... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: (raising his voice) Just do it! BEN exits. We follow BEN into the bullpen, past the STAFFERS who loo at the outburst... MOLLY watches BEN and then looks to STEPHEN who closes his door. We stay on MOLLY. We see MOLLY watching through the door... as STEPHEN finishes, he opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Molly... She gets up and comes into his office. Stephen hands Moll folder that he writes on the inside of

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Here... Molly opens the folder and reads "Meet me in the stairwel noon". She closes the folder.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Okay. Stephen holds out his hand.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: I'll take that. That's all. He takes the folder and tears it into several pieces as M leaves... he throws the pieces into the trash can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STEPHEN stands at a tellers counter, he writes out a chec for eight hundred dollars to cash. The teller hands him t money. Stephen exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STEPHEN walks down to the sidewalk. He's on the phone wit Ida. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pause. 62.

dialogues.speaker: IDA
dialogues.text: Stevie ... off the record ...

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: No I can't tell you what happened in North Carolina.

dialogues.speaker: IDA
dialogues.text: That's not what I wanted to ask you about.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: Okay what?

dialogues.speaker: IDA
dialogues.text: You met with Duffy.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: Who told you that?

dialogues.speaker: IDA
dialogues.text: A little bird.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: IDA
dialogues.text: Did you meet with him?

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: Where are you?

dialogues.speaker: IDA
dialogues.text: I know you met with him at a little bar in Cincy, two nights ago, just before the press conference. Duffy ordered buffalo wings.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: Did Duffy tell you this?

dialogues.speaker: IDA
dialogues.text: Anonymous. What happened with Duffy? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: You're supposed to be my friend Ida. You'd stab me in the back like this? You'd ruin my reputation just so you-

dialogues.speaker: IDA
dialogues.text: Wait wait wait -is that what you thought? That we were friends?

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: I've given you everything -every fucking scoop, your profile with Paul....

dialogues.speaker: IDA
dialogues.text: You're right -you've given me a lot. But let's get real here Steve. The only reason you ever treated me well was that I work for the Times. Not because I was your friend. You give me what I want, I write you better stories. Don't pretend it's any more than that. Why'd you meet with Duffy?

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: Go fuck yourself. STEPHEN starts walking away.

dialogues.speaker: IDA
dialogues.text: Okay, I'll make it easier on you. Forget Duffy. What happened at Paul and Thompson's meeting?

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: (Stopping) Will you keep your voice down. Do you have any idea what a story like this could do to me?

dialogues.speaker: IDA
dialogues.text: Of course I do. That's why I'm giving you a choice here.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: I could get fired.

dialogues.speaker: IDA
dialogues.text: So it's not a difficult choice, is it? I've got to file by three p.m. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: IDA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: tomorrow. make up your mind. You've got till then to Stephen is left standing there.

dialogues.speaker: A FEW MINUTES LATER
dialogues.text: Stephen is on a pay phone in at a campaign event, he also

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: You mother fucker.

dialogues.speaker: DUFFY
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: You leaked it.

dialogues.speaker: DUFFY
dialogues.text: Leaked what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: front of the fountain. talks on his cell. DUFFY is Don't bullshit me Tom.

dialogues.speaker: DUFFY
dialogues.text: Bullshit you...I have no idea what you're talking about. Horowicz. threatening to release the

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: I just spoke with Ida

dialogues.speaker: DUFFY
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: She's story.

dialogues.speaker: DUFFY
dialogues.text: What fucking story?

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN
dialogues.text: That we met! with you!
